entry.title: Rspecä¸­ä½¿ç”¨database_cleaner
entry.content:

åœ¨ä½¿ç”¨Rspecçš„è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­å› ä¸ºæœ‰ä½¿ç”¨ FactoryGirl ï¼Œå‘ç°åœ¨ä¸€äº›ç”¨ä¾‹ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨userçš„æ—¶å€™ä¼šå‘ç”Ÿ

Validation failed: Email has already been taken (ActiveRecord::RecordInvalid)

å› ä¸ºåœ¨ç”Ÿæˆuserçš„æ—¶å€™æ²¡æœ‰ä½¿ç”¨å•ä¾‹æ¨¡å¼ï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰æ¯æ¬¡å‘ FactoryGirl è¦ user çš„æ—¶å€™éƒ½ä¼šé‡æ–°ç”Ÿæˆæ–°çš„æ•°æ®ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å°±å’Œä¹‹å‰å‘ç”Ÿå†²çªäº†ã€‚

å‚è€ƒ ruby-china çš„æµ‹è¯•ä»£ç ï¼Œå‘ç°æ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨äº† database_cleaner ä½¿å¾—æ¯ä¸ªæµ‹è¯•ç”¨ä¾‹ä¹‹åæ¸…æ‰«äº†æµ‹è¯•æ•°æ®åº“ï¼Œå°±ä¸ä¼šå¼•å‘å†²çªäº†ã€‚

  config.before(:each) do

ä½†æ˜¯å½“æˆ‘æŠŠ database_cleaner é…ç½®å¥½å¹¶åŠ åˆ°æˆ‘é¡¹ç›® rspec ä¸­çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œå´é‡åˆ°äº†

ç½‘ä¸Šæœç´¢ä¸€å †æ— æ•ˆä¹‹åï¼Œè½¬è€Œä½¿ç”¨å¦å¤–ä¸€ä¸ªè§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆ

ä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯åœ¨è·‘å®Œæ¯ä¸ªæµ‹è¯•ç”¨ä¾‹ä¹‹åï¼Œåˆ é™¤æ‰æ•°æ®åº“ä¸­æ‰€æœ‰çš„ Model æ•°æ®

ç”±äºè¿™æ ·ä¸€æ®µä»£ç ï¼Œæ¥ä¸‹æ¥æˆ‘é‡åˆ°äº†ä¸€ä¸ªæ›´åŠ å¤´ç–¼çš„é—®é¢˜ã€‚å› ä¸ºæˆ‘ä½¿ç”¨ Devise çš„ sign_in user åœ¨æ¯ä¸ªæµ‹è¯•ç”¨ä¾‹ä¸­æ¥æ¨¡æ‹Ÿç™»é™†åçš„ç”¨æˆ·ï¼Œç»“æœå‘ç°ï¼Œå‰åä¸¤ä¸ªæµ‹è¯•ç”¨ä¾‹ï¼Œæ€»æ˜¯å‡ºç°ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªç”¨ä¾‹èƒ½é€šè¿‡ï¼Œç¬¬äºŒä¸ªç”¨ä¾‹æ­»æ´»é€šè¿‡ä¸äº†ã€‚

class TeamsController < ApplicationController
  before_action :authenticate_user!
end

# ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ª examples èƒ½é€šè¿‡ï¼Œç¬¬äºŒä¸ª examples æ— æ³•é€šè¿‡
describe TeamsController, :type => :controller do
  user = FactoryGirl.create(:user)

  describe ":index" do
    it "should show list of teams" do
      sign_in user
      get :index
      expect(response).to be_success
    end
  end

  describe ":new" do
    it "should allow access from authenticated user" do
      sign_in user
      get :new
      expect(response).to be_success
    end
  end

end

å°†ç¬¬äºŒä¸ª examples çš„ response.body æ‰“å°å‡ºæ¥ï¼Œå‘ç°

<html><body>You are being <a href="http://test.host/users/sign_in">redirected</a>.</body></html>

æ— è§£ï¼Œç„¶ååˆ†åˆ«æ‰“å°ä¸¤ä¸ªç”¨ä¾‹çš„ controller.current_userï¼Œå‘ç°åä¸€ä¸ªæ˜¯ nil

æœ€ç»ˆæˆ‘å°† database_cleaner å‡çº§åˆ°äº† 1.3.0 é‡æ–°bundleäº†ä¸€ä¸‹ï¼Œè§£å†³äº† superclass mismatch for class SQLite3Adapter çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼Œç§»é™¤äº†é‚£æ®µåˆ é™¤æ‰€æœ‰ Model æ•°æ®çš„ trick ä»£ç æ‰€æœ‰çš„é—®é¢˜å…¨éƒ¨è§£å†³äº†ã€‚

entry.title: Flask and Rails Part 1
entry.content:
I have written flask recently,with a little project that I can study python.

I used to write Ruby on Rails, which is a very famous web framework and the most popular web framework all over the world.Rails is really really fast to develop most web products,MVC with RESTful design makes very thing easy. Based on meta-programming, the ActiveRecord makes data handles fly in the air.

But flask is also an awesome web framework after a few days since I write my project.Itâ€™s more like sinatra,which is a light ruby web framework.

Request handle

With rails,you need to handle a request URL at routes.rb ruby get â€˜blogsâ€™ => â€˜blogs#indexâ€™ This code will handle /blogs GET method to a controller named blogs_controller.rb in app/controller/,and pass the params to function named index. After process the request,rails will render a view named index.html.erb in app/views/blogs/.

With flask,you need to handle a request URL at app.py python @app.route(â€˜/blogsâ€™) def index(): return render_template(â€˜index')

ORM

In my own words,ActiveRecord is much better than SQLAlchemy.

The Types of Associations in Rails:

  • belongs_to
  • has_one
  • has_many
  • has_many :through
  • has_one :through
  • has_and_belongs_to_many

Here are some data relationship implements of two ORM:

One to Many

With Rails:

class Customer < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_many :orders, dependent: :destroy
end

class Order < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :customer
end

Now you can get a customerâ€™s orders by: ruby @order = @customer.order.all() Get an orderâ€™s customer by: ruby @customer = @order.customer

With SQLAchemy:

class App(db.Model):
     __tablename__  = 'apps'
     owner_id       = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey(â€˜users.id'))
     owner          = db.relationship('User', backref=db.backref('appsâ€™))

class User(db.Model):
      __tablename__  =  'users'
       id            =  db.Column('id', db.Integer, primary_key=True)

Now you can get a userâ€™s apps by:

          app = user.apps

Get an appâ€™s owner by: python user = app.owner

Many to Many

Although you need migration files in rails,since Flask and SQLAlchemy just configure data structure within model.The benefit of migration files comes out when you want to change your data structure of model.And now I finally known why my teacher ask me to design data structure at first,because other web framework have no ideas about what if our data structure changed.

With migration files in rails, you can change you data structure so easy that you can develop really really align.All details about the program becomes more and more clear after you start coding.

entry.title: Rails è‡ªå®šä¹‰Rake Task æ¥å¤‡ä»½å’Œæ¢å¤æ•°æ®åº“
entry.content:
æ‰“å¼€Rakefileï¼Œæ·»åŠ 

namespace :db do
 task :backup do
   system "mysqldump --opt --user=root raiderboard > backup.sql"
 end


 task :restore do
   system "mysql --user=root raiderboard < backup.sql"
 end

end

ç„¶ååœ¨å‘½ä»¤è¡Œè¾“å…¥rake db:backupå°±èƒ½è·å¾—ä¸€ä»½sqlå¤‡ä»½æ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œgit/svn commitè¿™ä»½sqlæ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œåˆ°æœåŠ¡ç«¯git pullä¸‹æ¥ï¼Œç„¶åè¾“å…¥rake db:restoreä¾¿èƒ½æ¢å¤ä½ æœ¬åœ°çš„æ•°æ®åº“åˆ°æœåŠ¡ç«¯çš„æ•°æ®åº“äº†ã€‚

æŸ¥çœ‹æ•°æ®åº“å¤§å°

1 è¿›å»æŒ‡å®šschema æ•°æ®åº“ï¼ˆå­˜æ”¾äº†å…¶ä»–çš„æ•°æ®åº“çš„ä¿¡æ¯ï¼‰

mysql> use information_schema;
Database changed

2 æŸ¥è¯¢æ‰€æœ‰æ•°æ®çš„å¤§å°

mysql> select concat(round(sum(DATA_LENGTH/1024/1024), 2), 'MB')
-> as data from TABLES;  
+-----------+
| data      |
+-----------+
| 6674.48MB |
+-----------+
1 row in set (16.81 sec)

3 æŸ¥çœ‹æŒ‡å®šæ•°æ®åº“å®ä¾‹çš„å¤§å°ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚è¯´æ•°æ®åº“ forexpert

mysql> select concat(round(sum(DATA_LENGTH/1024/1024), 2), 'MB')
-> as data from TABLES where table_schema='forexpert';
+-----------+
| data      |
+-----------+
| 6542.30MB |
+-----------+
1 row in set (7.47 sec)

4 æŸ¥çœ‹æŒ‡å®šæ•°æ®åº“çš„è¡¨çš„å¤§å°ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚è¯´æ•°æ®åº“ forexpert ä¸­çš„ member è¡¨

mysql> select concat(round(sum(DATA_LENGTH/1024/1024),2),'MB') as data
-> from TABLES where table_schema='forexpert'
-> and table_name='member';
+--------+
| data   |
+--------+
| 2.52MB |
+--------+
1 row in set (1.88 sec)

entry.title: Rake Db åˆ—è¡¨åŠåŠŸèƒ½æ¦‚è¿°
entry.content:
• db:create creates the database for the current env
  • db:create:all creates the databases for all envs
  • db:drop drops the database for the current env
  • db:drop:all drops the databases for all envs
  • db:migrate runs migrations for the current env that have not run yet
  • db:migrate:up runs one specific migration
  • db:migrate:down rolls back one specific migration
  • db:migrate:status shows current migration status
  • db:migrate:rollback rolls back the last migration
  • db:forward advances the current schema version to the next one
  • db:seed (only) runs the db/seed.rb file
  • db:schema:load loads the schema into the current env’s database

  • db:schema:dump dumps the current env’s schema (and seems to create the db as well)

  • db:setup runs db:schema:load, db:seed

  • db:reset runs db:drop db:setup

  • db:migrate:redo runs (db:migrate:down db:migrate:up) or (db:migrate:rollback db:migrate:migrate) depending on the specified migration
  • db:migrate:reset runs db:drop db:create db:migrate
